messageBody:
Hi Eric
Thanks for your thoughtful questions.
I think that QS and the other Shavian Alphabets are the best way to
learn to spell English phonetically, however as most non-English-
speakers who want to learn how to pronounce British or American also
want to learn the regular Roman Alphabet, and English spelling with
that Alphabet is a different kettle of fish.

For ESL users, I would suggest using the Revised Pitman Alphabet
which adds a few additional letters and standardises the more
regular English Diagraphs. You can find a clear description of this
Alphabet under Pitman Initial Teaching Alphabetat www.omniglot.com
or at www.newenglishalphabets.com

English as a foreign language is also an interest of mine, and
that is the way I teach it.
Regards, Paul V.

P.S. I use the Revised Shaw Alphabet myself, as I prefer to use just
one phonetic system and one Non-Phonetic system (Roman) and never
the twain shall meet.
_____________________attached________________________

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Erik Felker" <ejfelker@...>
wrote:
>
> Thanks for your response. I see at least part of what you mean
about
> phonemic/phonetic, but the situation sounds like a bit of a blend
of
> the two, since our ways of speaking are often unconscious, and I
> assume that when we are writing in QS, we are listening to our own
> internal voices--for example, your internal voice that does not
make
> the sound distinction that you mentioned, and my internal voice
that
> does. I can also see QS as an excellent way of reproducing
regional
> accents for literary purposes. I can see that this is going to be
> quite an intellectual adventure!
>
> By the way, where do you find the news in QS?
>
> Also, I am still wondering if QS is being used as a way to help
> non-English-speakers learn how to pronounce British or American
> English... (English as a foreign language is an interest of mine,
and> a subject in which I have some tutoring experience.)
